events.description: The Nikkei 225 and Topix Index fell significantly on Friday, extending losses from the previous session.
A tech-led selloff on Wall Street that influenced Japanese markets.
Upcoming elections where the ruling LDP is expected to gain seats.

facts.fact_text: The Nikkei 225 fell 0.7% to below 53,500, while the broader Topix Index also dropped 0.7% to 3,626 on Friday.

evidences.evidence_text: The Nikkei 225 fell 0.7% to below 53,500, while the broader Topix Index also dropped 0.7% to 3,626 on Friday

facts.fact_text: Kioxia Holdings shares decreased by 5.6%, SoftBank Group fell 1.7%, and Advantest slid 3.5%.

evidences.evidence_text: Technology stocks led the losses in Japan, with Kioxia Holdings down 5.6%, SoftBank Group falling 1.7%, and Advantest sliding 3.5%.

facts.fact_text: Nintendo and Mitsubishi UFJ shares fell by 3.7% and 1.8% respectively.

evidences.evidence_text: Consumer and financial firms also came under pressure, including Nintendo (-3.7%) and Mitsubishi UFJ (-1.8%).

claims.claim_text: Concerns over massive artificial intelligence spending and potential disruption to software companies drove the decline.

evidences.evidence_text: Concerns over massive artificial intelligence spending and potential disruption to software companies drove the decline.

claims.claim_text: A broader selloff in metals and cryptocurrencies reflected widespread deleveraging across financial markets.

evidences.evidence_text: A broader selloff in metals and cryptocurrencies further weighed on risk sentiment, reflecting widespread deleveraging across financial markets.

claims.claim_text: The ruling LDP is expected to gain seats and pursue expansionary fiscal policies under Prime Minister Sane Takaichi.

evidences.evidence_text: the ruling LDP is expected to gain seats and pursue expansionary fiscal policies under Prime Minister Sane Takaichi.

evidence.evidence_text: extending losses from the previous session amid a tech-led selloff on Wall Street.
Concerns over massive artificial intelligence spending and potential disruption to software companies drove the decline.
reflecting widespread deleveraging across financial markets.
the ruling LDP is expected to gain seats and pursue expansionary fiscal policies
